3. Getting started¶

3.1. Pure component chemical properties.¶

Chemical objects contain pure component properties:

In [1]:

import thermosteam as tmo
# Initialize with an identifier (e.g. name, CAS, InChI...)
water = tmo.Chemical('Water')
water # All attributes of a chemical are presented in the IPython display

Chemical: Water (phase_ref='l')
[Names]  CAS: 7732-18-5
         InChI: H2O/h1H2
         InChI_key: XLYOFNOQVPJJNP-U...
         common_name: water
         iupac_name: oxidane
         pubchemid: 962
         smiles: O
[Groups] Dortmund: <1H2O>
         UNIFAC: <1H2O>
         PSRK: <1H2O>
[Thermo] S_excess(phase, T, P) -> J/mol
         H_excess(phase, T, P) -> J/mol
         mu(phase, T, P) -> Pa*s
         kappa(phase, T, P) -> W/m/K
         V(phase, T, P) -> m^3/mol
         S(phase, T, P) -> J/mol
         H(phase, T) -> J/mol
         Cn(phase, T) -> J/mol/K
         Psat(T, P=None) -> Pa
         Hvap(T, P=None) -> J/mol
         sigma(T, P=None) -> N/m
         epsilon(T, P=None)
[Data]   MW: 18.015 g/mol
         Tm: 273.15 K
         Tb: 373.12 K
         Tt: 273.15 K
         Tc: 647.14 K
         Pc: 2.2048e+07 Pa
         Vc: 5.6e-05 m^3/mol
         Zc: 0.22947
         Hf: -2.4182e+05 J/mol
         Hc: 0 J/mol
         Hfus: 6010 J/mol
         omega: 0.344
         dipole: 1.85
         similarity_variable: 0.16653

The names are strings of chemical identifiers:

In [2]:

water.CAS

Out[2]:

'7732-18-5'

The groups are dictionaries of functional groups identifiers for the estimation of activity coefficients through group contribution methods:

In [3]:

water.Dortmund

Out[3]:

<DortmundGroupCounts: 1H2O>

The keys are group designation numbers and the values are the number of each group:

In [4]:

dict(water.Dortmund)

Out[4]:

{16: 1}

Temperature (in Kelvin) and pressure (in Pascal) dependent properties can be computed through the functors:

In [5]:

# Calculate vapor pressure (Pa)
water.Psat(T=373.15)

Out[5]:

101284.55179999319

In [6]:

# Calculate surface tension (N/m)
water.sigma(T=298.15)

Out[6]:

0.07205503890847455

In [7]:

# Calculate molar volume (m^3/mol)
water.V(T=298.15, P=101325, phase='l')

Out[7]:

1.687456798143492e-05

In [8]:

# Calculate enthalpy at reference conditions (J/mol; without excess energies)
water.H(T=298.15, phase='l')

Out[8]:

0.0

Note that the reference state of all chemicals is 25 C and 1 atm:

In [9]:

water.T_ref

Out[9]:

298.15

In [10]:

water.P_ref

Out[10]:

101325.0

Constant pure component properties are also available:

In [11]:

# Molecular weight (g/mol)
water.MW

Out[11]:

18.01528

In [12]:

# Boiling point (K)
water.Tb

Out[12]:

373.124

3.2. Functors¶

Temperature dependent properties are managed by model handles (a functor):

In [13]:

water.Psat

TDependentModelHandle(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
[0] Wagner_McGraw
[1] Antoine
[2] DIPPR_EQ101
[3] Wagner
[4] Boiling_Critical_Relation
[5] Lee_Kesler
[6] Ambrose_Walton
[7] Sanjari
[8] Edalat

A model handle contains a series of models applicable to a certain domain:

In [14]:

water.Psat[0]

TDependentModel: Wagner_McGraw
 evaluate: Wagner_McGraw(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 Tmin: 275.00
 Tmax: 647.35

When called, the model handle searches through each model until it finds one with an applicable domain. If none are applicable, you get a value error:

In [15]:

water.Psat(1000.0)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-15-020628acba16> in <module>
----> 1 water.Psat(1000.0)

~\OneDrive\Code\thermosteam\thermosteam\base\thermo_model_handle.py in __call__(self, T, P)
    127             if model.indomain(T): return model.evaluate(T)
    128         # return model.evaluate(T)
--> 129         raise ValueError(f"{repr(self)} contains no valid model at T={T:.2f} K")
    130
    131     def differentiate_by_T(self, T, P=None, dT=1e-12):

ValueError: <TDependentModelHandle(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]> contains no valid model at T=1000.00 K

Each model contains a functor that stores data to compute the property:

In [16]:

functor = water.Psat[0].evaluate
functor

Functor: Wagner_McGraw(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
 a: -7.7645
 b: 1.4584
 c: -2.7758
 d: -1.233
 Tc: 647.35 K
 Pc: 2.2122e+07 Pa

In [17]:

functor.function

Out[17]:

<function thermosteam.functors.vapor_pressure.Wagner_McGraw(T, a, b, c, d, Tc, Pc)>

In [18]:

functor.data

Out[18]:

{'a': -7.7645100000000005,
 'b': 1.45838,
 'c': -2.7758,
 'd': -1.2330299999999998,
 'Tc': 647.35,
 'Pc': 22122300}

It may be useful to look at the math:

In [19]:

tmo.settings.dark_mode = False # Default is True
functor.math

In [20]:

# For further help...
functor.help()


    Create a functor of temperature (T; in K) that returns the saturated vapor pressure (Psat; in Pa) using the Wagner McGraw equation, as described in [1]_.

    .. math::
       \ln P^{sat}= \ln P_c + \frac{a\tau + b \tau^{1.5} + c\tau^3 + d\tau^6} {T_r}

       \tau = 1 - \frac{T}{T_c}

    Parameters
    ----------
    Tc : float
        Critical point temperature [K].
    Pc : float
        Critical point pressure [Pa].
    a, b, c, d : float
        Regressed coefficients.

    Notes
    -----
    Warning: Pc is often treated as adjustable constant.

    Examples
    --------
    Methane, coefficients from [2]_, at 100 K.

    >>> Wagner_McGraw(100.0, a=-6.00435, b=1.1885,
    ... c=-0.834082, d=-1.22833, Tc=190.53, Pc=4596420.)
    34520.44601450496

    References
    ----------
    .. [1] Poling, Bruce E. The Properties of Gases and Liquids. 5th edition.
       New York: McGraw-Hill Professional, 2000.
    .. [2] McGarry, Jack. "Correlation and Prediction of the Vapor Pressures of
       Pure Liquids over Large Pressure Ranges." Industrial & Engineering
       Chemistry Process Design and Development 22, no. 2 (April 1, 1983):
       313-22. doi:10.1021/i200021a023.

Phase dependent properties have attributes with model handles for each phase:

In [21]:

water.V

Out[21]:

<ChemicalPhaseTPProperty(phase, T, P) -> V [m^3/mol]>

In [22]:

water.V.l, water.V.g

Out[22]:

(<TPDependentModelHandle(T, P) -> V.l [m^3/mol]>,
 <TPDependentModelHandle(T, P) -> V.g [m^3/mol]>)

Note: It is not required to use these models. They can be replaced by your own function or even a constant as shown in the next section.

3.3. Pure component thermodynamic models¶

The models are ordered in a deque object to allow for easy reordering:

In [23]:

water.Psat.models

Out[23]:

deque([<TDependentModel: Wagner_McGraw>,
       <TDependentModel: Antoine>,
       <TDependentModel: DIPPR_EQ101>,
       <TDependentModel: Wagner>,
       <TDependentModel: Boiling_Critical_Relation>,
       <TDependentModel: Lee_Kesler>,
       <TDependentModel: Ambrose_Walton>,
       <TDependentModel: Sanjari>,
       <TDependentModel: Edalat>])

In [24]:

water.Psat.models.rotate(-1)
water.Psat.models

Out[24]:

deque([<TDependentModel: Antoine>,
       <TDependentModel: DIPPR_EQ101>,
       <TDependentModel: Wagner>,
       <TDependentModel: Boiling_Critical_Relation>,
       <TDependentModel: Lee_Kesler>,
       <TDependentModel: Ambrose_Walton>,
       <TDependentModel: Sanjari>,
       <TDependentModel: Edalat>,
       <TDependentModel: Wagner_McGraw>])

You could also insert your own model:

In [26]:

@water.Psat.model(Tmin=273.20, Tmax=473.20, top=True) # top=True to append left
def User_antoine_model(T):
    return 10.0**(10.116 -  1687.537 / (T + 42.98))

water.Psat

TDependentModelHandle(T, P=None) -> Psat [Pa]
[0] User_antoine_model
[1] user_antoine_model
[2] Antoine
[3] DIPPR_EQ101
[4] Wagner
[5] Boiling_Critical_Relation
[6] Lee_Kesler
[7] Ambrose_Walton
[8] Sanjari
[9] Edalat
[10] Wagner_McGraw

You can also set a constant model:

In [29]:

water.V.l.model(1.687e-05)

ConstantThermoModel: Constant
 value: 1.687e-05
 Tmin: 0 K
 Tmax: inf K
 Pmin: 0 Pa
 Pmax: inf Pa

3.4. Ideal mixtures¶

In the next example, we make an ideal mixture property package from chemicals:

In [32]:

water =  tmo.Chemical('Water')
ethanol = tmo.Chemical('Ethanol')
methanol = tmo.Chemical('Methanol')
lignin = tmo.Chemical('Lignin')
ideal_mixture = tmo.mixture.IdealMixture(chemicals=(water, ethanol, methanol, lignin))
ideal_mixture

Out[32]:

IdealMixture([Water, Ethanol, Methanol, Lignin])

In [33]:

ideal_mixture.H

Out[33]:

<bound method IdealMixture.H of IdealMixture([Water, Ethanol, Methanol, Lignin])>

In [35]:

ideal_mixture.H('l', [0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4], 350, 101325)

Out[35]:

54404.253795065866

In [ ]:
